## News Review for kyocera

# Kyocera Technology News Review

## Executive Summary

Kyocera demonstrated significant technological advancement across multiple sectors during this period, most notably achieving a breakthrough 5.2 Gbps underwater optical communication link speed in November 2024—2.5 times faster than traditional systems—positioning the company as a leader in the rapidly growing underwater wireless communication market projected to reach $25.29 billion by 2035. The company expanded its industrial footprint through a strategic partnership with Utility Global to manufacture electrochemical cells for industrial decarbonization at its North Carolina facility beginning in 2026, leveraging its advanced ceramics capabilities for clean hydrogen production systems targeting steel, refining, and petrochemical industries. Kyocera's materials technology gained recognition across diverse applications, from synthetic opal materials used in luxury watch manufacturing to participation in Japan's strategic Rapidus semiconductor initiative as a components supplier for domestic 2nm chip production by 2027. The company also introduced Meta-Lens technology featuring ultra-thin, flat lens designs for advanced light control applications, while maintaining its position in established markets including automotive touch screen systems (projected to grow to $14.76 billion by 2030) and copier systems, demonstrating the breadth of Kyocera's technology portfolio across emerging and traditional sectors.

## Key Developments

**Product Launches and Technology Breakthroughs:**
- Achieved record-breaking 5.2 Gbps underwater optical communication link speed in November 2024, enabling data transfers that previously took hours to complete within seconds ([Spectrum IEEE](https://spectrum.ieee.org/underwater-communication-kyocera))
- Introduced Meta-Lens technology featuring ultra-thin, flat lens designs for advanced light control applications ([FOSS Weekly](https://itsfoss.com/newsletter/foss-weekly-25-52/))
- Demonstrated lab speeds up to 5.2 Gbps with offshore testing achieving 0.75 Gbps at 15 centimeters distance, claimed as a world UWOC record ([Spectrum IEEE](https://spectrum.ieee.org/underwater-communication-kyocera))

**Strategic Partnerships:**
- Entered partnership with Utility Global to manufacture electrochemical cells for H2Gen industrial decarbonization systems at Kyocera's North Carolina Fine Ceramics facility, with initial operations planned for 2026 ([PR Newswire](https://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/utility-global-and-kyocera-join-forces-to-scale-h2gen-manufacturing-globally-for-economic-industrial-decarbonization-302638725.html))
- Identified as components supplier among 22 companies considering investments in Japan's Rapidus semiconductor foundry project targeting 2nm chip production by 2027 ([Asia Times](https://asiatimes.com/2025/12/japans-rapidus-set-to-rival-tsmc-and-samsung-for-chip-supremacy/))
- GNSS antennas included in Nordic Semiconductor's nRF9151 SMA Development Kit for cellular IoT and satellite connectivity applications ([PR Newswire](https://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/nordic-semiconductor-launches-nrf9151-software-and-development-kit-combining-satellite-and-cellular-iot-connectivity-302638265.html))

**Materials Technology Applications:**
- Lab-grown opal material selected by Venezianico for limited-edition Nereide Opale dive watch dials, composed of 80% silica and 20% clear resin, addressing production consistency challenges with natural opal ([Yanko Design](https://www.yankodesign.com/2025/12/23/the-dial-that-swallowed-the-watch/))

## Market Context

Kyocera's developments align with several major technology trends driving market growth. The underwater optical communication breakthrough positions the company in a market projected to reach $25.29 billion by 2035 with 14.7% CAGR, driven by defense, offshore energy, and scientific research applications. The partnership with Utility Global for industrial decarbonization manufacturing addresses accelerating demand for clean technology solutions in heavy industries. Kyocera's participation in Japan's Rapidus semiconductor initiative reflects the country's strategic push for domestic chip manufacturing independence, reducing dependence on Taiwan and China for advanced semiconductors. The company maintains recognition across established markets including automotive touch screen systems (growing to $14.76 billion by 2030), advanced materials (projected to double to $275.41 billion by 2035), and fuel cells (reaching $18.16 billion by 2030 with 26.3% CAGR), demonstrating its diversified technology portfolio spanning emerging and traditional sectors.

## Notable Quotes

**Jeff Osmun, Vice President of Kyocera International, Inc., Fine Ceramics Group** stated regarding the Utility Global partnership: "The collaboration between our two companies will make this partnership a rapid success and provide high performance, high quality electrochemical cells for Utility. As a global leader and producer of advanced engineered ceramic materials and components, we are seeking to leverage our existing and future capabilities to help enable carbon neutralization. This is in line with Kyocera's philosophy, which aims to solve social issues through its business activities and realize a sustainable society. Partnering with Utility is another major step in that direction." ([PR Newswire](https://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/utility-global-and-kyocera-join-forces-to-scale-h2gen-manufacturing-globally-for-economic-industrial-decarbonization-302638725.html))

**Yoshitaka Toeda, member of the advanced research group at Kyocera** explained the underwater communication system: "Together, these components enable gigabit data-rate communications throughout the system," referring to the optimized blue-laser system, sensitive receiver, and multi-channel data splitting architecture. ([Spectrum IEEE](https://spectrum.ieee.org/underwater-communication-kyocera))

**Ryota Kimura, researcher in Kyocera's communication systems R&D division** confirmed real-world testing validation: "It allowed us to assess how stable and reliable the prototype was under various conditions," and provided concrete performance metrics: "we were able to communicate over distances ranging from 15 centimeters to 1.5 meters. That gave us a clear picture of the prototype's performance in a real-world environment." ([Spectrum IEEE](https://spectrum.ieee.org/underwater-communication-kyocera))

## Strategic Implications

Kyocera's recent developments demonstrate a strategic expansion beyond traditional electronics into high-growth technology sectors while leveraging existing manufacturing capabilities. The underwater optical communication breakthrough establishes the company as a technology leader in a niche but rapidly growing market, with plans for a 2 Gbps commercial version by 2027 and showcase at the 2026 Consumer Electronics Show. The industrial decarbonization partnership represents a strategic pivot toward sustainability applications, aligning with global decarbonization trends while utilizing Kyocera's advanced ceramics expertise for new revenue streams. Participation in Japan's Rapidus semiconductor initiative positions Kyocera within national strategic technology development, potentially expanding its role in advanced chip manufacturing supply chains. The diverse technology portfolio spanning underwater communications, industrial decarbonization, automotive electronics, and advanced materials positions Kyocera to capture opportunities across multiple high-growth markets while reducing dependence on any single sector. The company's focus on solving social issues through business activities, as articulated by executives, suggests a strategic emphasis on sustainability and societal impact as key differentiators in competitive markets.

### Article 2: Japan's Rapidus set to rival TSMC and Samsung for chip supremacy - Asia Times

**Source:** [View Full Article](https://asiatimes.com/2025/12/japans-rapidus-set-to-rival-tsmc-and-samsung-for-chip-supremacy/)

## Summary

Kyocera has been identified as a components supplier among 22 companies considering investments in Japan's Rapidus semiconductor foundry project, which aims to establish domestic 2nm chip manufacturing by 2027. This participation positions Kyocera within Japan's strategic initiative to reduce dependence on foreign semiconductor suppliers, particularly Taiwan's TSMC, and could expand the company's role in advanced chip manufacturing components as part of a broader national industrial coalition including Honda, Canon, and Fujitsu.



---

### Article 3: The Dial That Swallowed the Watch

**Source:** [View Full Article](https://www.yankodesign.com/2025/12/23/the-dial-that-swallowed-the-watch/)

## Summary

Kyocera's lab-grown opal material has been selected by Italian watchmaker Venezianico for the dial of their limited-edition Nereide Opale dive watch, demonstrating the company's materials technology extending into luxury consumer goods. The synthetic material, composed of 80% silica and 20% clear resin, reproduces the color-shifting properties of natural opal while providing manufacturing consistency and thermal stability that natural stones cannot guarantee, addressing production challenges in the 500-piece limited run priced at $1,395.



---

### Article 4: Kyocera’s Subsea Laser Link Swaps Range for Gigabit Speeds

**Source:** [View Full Article](https://spectrum.ieee.org/underwater-communication-kyocera)

## Summary

Kyocera demonstrated underwater optical wireless communication technology in November 2024, achieving lab speeds of 5.2 Gbps and offshore testing results of 0.75 Gbps at 15 centimeters distance, which the company claims as a world UWOC record. The system uses blue-laser technology with gallium nitride semiconductors, targeting underwater drone inspections of oil and gas infrastructure where current acoustic modems only provide kilobit-speed data transfer. Kyocera researchers are developing a 1 Gbps prototype and plan a 2 Gbps commercial version by 2027, with the technology being showcased at the 2026 Consumer Electronics Show.

## Executive Insights

**Yoshitaka Toeda, member of the advanced research group at Kyocera**

> "Together, these components enable gigabit data-rate communications throughout the system"

*Context: Explaining how optimized blue-laser system, sensitive receiver, and multi-channel data splitting work together*

*Significance: Technical validation of Kyocera's underwater optical communication system architecture*

**Ryota Kimura, researcher in Kyocera's communication systems R&D division**

> "It allowed us to assess how stable and reliable the prototype was under various conditions"

*Context: Discussing offshore testing of the underwater optical communication system*

*Significance: Confirms real-world testing validation beyond laboratory conditions*

**Ryota Kimura, researcher in Kyocera's communication systems R&D division**

> "we were able to communicate over distances ranging from 15 centimeters to 1.5 meters. That gave us a clear picture of the prototype's performance in a real-world environment"

*Context: Results from seawater testing of the prototype system*

*Significance: Provides concrete performance metrics for the underwater communication technology*

### Article 11: Underwater Wireless Communication Market Set to Reach US$ 25.29 Billion by 2035 | Astute Analytica

**Source:** [View Full Article](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2025/12/11/3204016/0/en/Underwater-Wireless-Communication-Market-Set-to-Reach-US-25-29-Billion-by-2035-Astute-Analytica.html)

## Summary

Kyocera demonstrated a 5.2 Gbps underwater optical communication link in November 2025, achieving speeds 2.5 times faster than traditional underwater optical systems and enabling data transfers that previously took hours to complete within seconds. This breakthrough positions Kyocera as a technology leader in the underwater wireless communication market, which is projected to reach $25.29 billion by 2035 with a 14.7% CAGR. The technology addresses growing demand from defense, offshore energy, and scientific research applications, with industry participants viewing optical wireless technology as the preferred solution for video transmission and rapid data offload tasks in autonomous underwater vehicle operations.

### Article 13: Utility Global and Kyocera Join Forces to Scale H2Gen® Manufacturing Globally for Economic Industrial Decarbonization

**Source:** [View Full Article](https://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/utility-global-and-kyocera-join-forces-to-scale-h2gen-manufacturing-globally-for-economic-industrial-decarbonization-302638725.html)

## Summary

Kyocera International has partnered with Utility Global to manufacture electrochemical cells for industrial decarbonization systems, establishing production at its North Carolina Fine Ceramics facility with operations beginning in 2026. The partnership leverages Kyocera's advanced ceramics manufacturing capabilities to produce ceramic-metal electrochemical cells for H2Gen systems that generate clean hydrogen from industrial off-gases without electricity, targeting steel, refining, petrochemical and chemical industries. Jeff Osmun, VP of Kyocera's Fine Ceramics Group, stated the collaboration aligns with Kyocera's philosophy of solving social issues through business activities and represents a step toward enabling carbon neutralization, positioning the company in the growing industrial decarbonization market.

## Executive Insights

**Jeff Osmun, Vice President of Kyocera International, Inc., Fine Ceramics Group**

> "The collaboration between our two companies will make this partnership a rapid success and provide high performance, high quality electrochemical cells for Utility. As a global leader and producer of advanced engineered ceramic materials and components, we are seeking to leverage our existing and future capabilities to help enable carbon neutralization. This is in line with Kyocera's philosophy, which aims to solve social issues through its business activities and realize a sustainable society. Partnering with Utility is another major step in that direction."

*Context: Discussing the strategic partnership with Utility Global for electrochemical cell manufacturing*

*Significance: Indicates Kyocera's strategic direction toward sustainability applications and leveraging existing ceramic capabilities for new markets*
